reporting-org.narrative: Association des Editeurs du Magazine Jimbere

title.narrative: Share-Net Burundi

description.narrative: Established in 2014, Share-Net Burundi is the knowledge platform on Sexual and reproductive health and Rights (SRHR). With a focus on youth, its mission is to improve Burundian SRHR through open communication, knowledge-sharing, research facilitation, and advocacy geared towards healthy policy-making. SN-BU has 70 organisational members from sectors including academia, policy makers, practitioners and NGOs and 20 individual members. The platform is strong of five Communities of Practices: Adolescents and Youth Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights, Media in SRHR, HIV/AIDS, Menstrual Health, Family planning. Share-Net Burundi is one of the 7 national hubs that are part of Share-Net International. Since July 2020, Share-Net Burundi is hosted by Jimbere Magazine Publishers Association (ASSEMAJI) whose main project, Jimbere Magazine, is a monthly publication conceived as a media platform that is generally committed to training, educating and entertaining the youth of Burundi, with a special emphasis on the status of women.

participating-org.narrative: Association des Editeurs du Magazine Jimbere

title.narrative: Networking at national (CoP) and international level (partners)

description.narrative: Networking and matchmaking

title.narrative: Number of new (inter)national partnerships established

description.narrative: Efforts SN has made to broaden its network

comment.narrative: This is the most notable partnership , Share-Net Burundi has received funding from the Dutch Embassy in Burundi to coordinate a large sexual and reproductive health project (SRHR Solutions) involving several national and international organizations working in this field. The first cycle (two years out of four) of this project started on July 1, 2021 and will end on June 30, 2023.

title.narrative: Networking at national (CoP) and international level (partners)

description.narrative: Networking and matchmaking

title.narrative: Number of active Communities of Practice

description.narrative: Number of CoPs that have been established and their respective topics

comment.narrative: In Burundi, all of the existing national communities of practice are active except for the infertility community of practice, where members are not active because there is little knowledge available and also less investment in this area. With WHO, we have discussed how to revitalize this community of practice but for now much of the effort is directed towards family planning and other issues of interest to the government.
